Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Leveraging Noncontact Dimensional Metrology to Understand Complex Part-to-Part Variation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to develop a paradigm for identifying and visualizing complex part-to-part variation patterns in high-dimensional, spatially dense optical coordinate measuring machine (OCMM) data. OCMMs for noncontact dimensional metrology using laser and/or vision systems are one of the most promising emerging measurement technologies for quality control in discrete parts manufacturing. They produce large volumes of profile, point cloud, and high resolution image data that represent parametric and nonparametric surface geometry characteristics. The emphasis of this award on part-to-part variation is fundamentally different than the emphasis of current OCMM data analysis software, which fits geometric features separately to individual parts. To create the proposed paradigm for understanding variation, a manifold learning framework for identifying and visualizing the variation patterns will be developed, addressing challenges that include simultaneously identifying nonparametric and parametric variation patterns, handling measurement noise structure that differs from what is typically assumed in manifold learning, transforming OCMM data to reduce the extent of nonlinearity in the patterns, and handling heterogeneous data types obtained at different process stages.

If successful, the results of this research will provide a powerful tool to facilitate the discovery and elimination of major root causes of manufacturing variation. Many discrete parts manufacturing industries invest heavily in OCMM equipment but lack knowledge discovery tools for fully utilizing the technology to understand part-to-part variation. This research will fill a critical void by creating a methodology for more effectively analyzing high-dimensional, spatially dense OCMM data. It will provide more sophisticated, badly needed variation reduction tools suitable for manufacturing six-sigma programs that employ modern OCMM technology, which will increase the competitiveness of US manufacturers. It will also allow for a greater return on investment in OCMM technology, which is expected to increase demand for the hardware/software systems and spark further advances in the technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most major companies invest heavily in advanced measurement and data collection technology for manufacturing quality assurance. One measurement technology that is broadly applicable in manufacturing is noncontact dimensional metrology using laser and/or vision systems. Such optical coordinate measuring machines (OCMMs) produce large volumes of profile, point cloud, and high resolution image data that represent surface geometry characteristics. OCMM accuracy and throughput are now at levels that render it suitable for quality control of parts with reasonably high precision, and there is existing work on analyzing OCMM data that pertains to fitting specific geometric features for individual parts for verifying the dimensional integrity of the parts. However, although there is also a wealth of information on the nature of part-to-part variation buried in the rich and complex structure of the spatially dense OCMM data, there is currently no comprehensive and generic approach for uncovering this information.

The primary broad goal of this research is to fill this void via a paradigm to identify and visualize complex part-to-part variation patterns in high-dimensional, spatially dense OCMM data, which provides a powerful tool to facilitate the discovery and elimination of major root causes of manufacturing variation. Many manufacturing industries invest heavily in OCMM equipment, but lack knowledge discovery tools to fully utilize the technology to understand part-to-part variation. A broader goal of this research is to fill this critical void to create methodology to more effectively analyze high-dimensional, spatially dense OCMM data, to provide more sophisticated, badly needed variation reduction tools suitable for manufacturing programs, and which will ultimately increase the competitiveness of US manufacturers. It will also allow for a greater return on investment in OCMM technology, which will increase demand for the hardware/software systems and spark further advances in the technology.

Therefore, the proposed methodology for discovering information from raw OCMM data represents a critical advancement in data analysis to keep pace with the tremendous advancements in noncontact dimensional metrology and data in recent years.

A broadly applicable approach was created for any type of OCMM data, requiring no prior knowledge of anticipated patterns, although such knowledge can be incorporated if available. To achieve this goal, we created

Manifold learning (nonlinear structure) framework to identify and visualize the nature of variation in a sample of measured profiles

New nonlinear denoising approach for reducing noise in OCMM data for a sample of parts

Method to extract latent nonlinear variation patterns based on deep autoencoders

Important seminal method to learn distinct nonlinear variation patterns and a to quantify the distinctness of learned features based on deep learning

Challenges addressed included simultaneously identifying nonparametric and parametric variation patterns, handling measurement noise structures that differ from what is typically assumed in manifold learning, transforming OCMM data to reduce the extent of nonlinearity in the patterns, and learning distinct variation patterns.

Manifold learning and variation pattern discovery are emerging areas in high-dimensional multivariate statistical analysis. However, they has not previously been investigated for manufacturing variation reduction. Because of the importance of manufacturing quality, and the pervasiveness of OCMM data in manufacturing, this research has opened up a rich and far-reaching application domain in which these methods can be further developed. More generally, development of related algorithms in the will lead to better insight into the general capabilities of these algorithms, which in turn will lead to general improvements in and enhancements of the algorithms.

Furthermore, the methodology is more generally applicable. The techniques created here extend from this basic OCMM data to high-dimensional data that occurs in numerous other scientific and engineering domains. For variation pattern discovery, it is important that latent features be distinct in the sense that they represent unique sources of variation in the data. This research addressed this important research gap. A measure was constructed to quantify the distinctness of features and an alternating learning algorithm was generated for nonlinear pattern analysis. Validation studies showed the algorithm’s effectiveness to capture distinct patterns. Methods were then extended to learn variation patterns through regularized deep learning. Open-source deep learning software was modified to identify distinct patterns to understand the nature of variability. The work on learning of distinct variation patterns is seminal and important to a number of disciplines from manufacturing to health. The work here has identified and emphasized the importance of this issue. This research started with spatially derived re-indexing for manufacturing, but transitioned to modified methods that learn distinct patterns through regularized terms in the latest deep learning algorithms.

A number of graduate students have gained experience with research that addresses an important practical need. They also learned to develop computer software to modify and test algorithms. The results will be integrated into statistical learning courses that the PIs teach to graduate students and to an ethnically diverse spectrum of engineers and technical managers in professional masters' courses.

 


Last Modified: 11/19/2016
Modified by: George C Runger

One measurement technology that is broadly applicable in manufacturing is noncontact dimensional metrology using laser and/or vision systems. Such optical coordinate measuring machines (OCMMs) produce large volumes of profile, point cloud, and high resolution image data that represent surface geometry characteristics. OCMM accuracy and throughput are now at levels that render it suitable for quality control of parts with reasonably high precision, and there is existing work on analyzing OCMM data that pertains to fitting specific geometric features for individual parts for verifying the dimensional integrity of the parts. However, although there is also a wealth of information on the nature of part-to-part variation buried in the rich and complex structure of the spatially dense OCMM data, there is currently no comprehensive and generic approach for uncovering this information. The primary broad goal of this research is to fill this void via a paradigm to identify and visualize complex part-to-part variation patterns in high-dimensional, spatially dense OCMM data, which provides a powerful tool to facilitate the discovery and elimination of major root causes of manufacturing variation. Many manufacturing industries invest heavily in OCMM equipment, but lack knowledge discovery tools to fully utilize the technology to understand part-to-part variation. The work on learning of distinct variation patterns is seminal and important to a number of disciplines from manufacturing to health. The results will be integrated into statistical learning courses that the PIs teach to graduate students and to an ethnically diverse spectrum of engineers and technical managers in professional masters' courses.
